conversations.text: I will give you some text describing a fantasy/scify world. After reading that text, could you walk me through the creation of a carachter in this world while filling all necessary gaps with your imagination?

Of course! I'll do my best to help you create a character for this world based on the description you provide.

Please go ahead and give me the text describing the fantasy/sci-fi world, and I'll get started on helping you create a character.

The World Of Tormentosia
Since the beginning of time, the kingdoms and
people of Tormentosia have been fi ghting for
wealth, territory, or simply power. Confl icts and
wars were so omnipresent and plentiful that one
could speak of “The Eternal Wars”, but that all
changed abruptly 25 years ago, when a new threat
emerged. A threat so dangerous it could wipe out
everything and everyone.
As the southern sky darkened, a moon fell onto the
world. From the fi res created by the impact rose
a fi gure that would later be called “Sorgoth the
Devourer of Worlds”. With it came the Gothkin, an
army of half-digested creatures it spat out to ruin
the world. The entity and its army obliterated most
of the thirty-six existing realms, leaving the rest to
fi ght a slowly losing battle.
Only six kingdoms remained and these agreed on
a truce to focus on the common enemy and protect
what was left of the world. They formed the Core
Nation and built the city of Coreheim which sits in
the center of the remaining territories. This city
became a hub for all other kingdoms and offered
people shelter who once lived in now destroyed
parts of the world. It also served another reason:
The construction of the Ultracore. A shield-pulse-
generator that is capable of creating a protective
energy wall that can extend over vast distances
around the remaining realms. A technology origi-
nally invented by the Nosmerians to defeat the other
kingdoms and thereby emerge victorious from the
Eternal Wars. However, they never managed to
fi nish it, because essential components and work
steps were still missing. With the help of the other
kingdoms these steps can fi nally be accomplished.
Consequently, every nation is doing their part for
the completion of the Ultracore, in order to save
what is left of the world.

The Six Kingdoms And Their Races
Tormentosia is a world of whimsy and wonder.
There are countless beings, races and factions.
Electricity is existent, and nifty mechanisms and
energy sources are available and treated more like
mana or magic. They are available in many unique
shapes such as steam engines, fi rearms or indi-
vidual customizable contraptions. The different
types of technologies are linked to specifi c realms,
making them available only to certain races. In the
following the remaining kingdoms and
their dominant inhabitants are described.

Would you like me to also provide desciptions of the different areas and people in this world?
Yes, please! Any additional information you can provide about the world and its inhabitants will be helpful in creating a character.

AMBROS
Ambros, the kissed land. The home of wealth, yield,
and the most fertile soil of all empires. Crystal clear
rivers wind their way through evergreen valleys.
Thereby, passing fruit trees and endless fi elds,
tilled by people with velvety skin, who might not be
the ones who enjoy this abundance. Ambros is the
Hedonists‘ home, they rule this realm and in earlier
days many others with their wealth. In Ambros,
there is nothing that makes your days appear idle.
To the east, it borders the Liquid Meadows and in
the north the emerald prairies of the Litikal Planes.
HEDONISTS
A nation of people who put lust and pleasure at the
center of their being. The Hedonists live their days
in pure bliss and should problems arise, they surely
can be solved by throwing money at it. Even the
low-ranking workers among them are rich enough
to indulge in luxuries that the inhabitants of the
other realms could only dream of. Certainly, such
opulence attracts envy, which is not really welcome
in Ambros.
To ward these people off, the top Hedonists chose
the most noble within their own ranks to be Prae-
torians; elite warriors who dedicate their lives to
fi ghting with the two-handed sword against anyone
who threatens the improving lifestyle of the higher-
ranking Hedonists. Additionally, since the Ultracore
pact, they have been responsible for its protection
and the order in the Core Nation. When the World
Ender robbed uncounted people of Tormentosia
of their homes, the troops of the Praetorians were
increased at the request of Queen Julia of Ambros
and common people were also allowed to join their
ranks.
The Hedonists live in a clearly hierarchical society
that attaches tremendous importance to nobility,
ancestry and generally descent. Other nations are
treated in a rather derogatory manner. They see
the Ultracore pact as more of a necessary evil than
something they value.
in pure bliss and should problems arise, they surely
06
ASCILIATH
Asciliath is an ancient realm, buried under snow
and shrouded in never ending darkness. Its high,
razor-sharp mountain peaks keep the clouds
fi rmly under their control, so that hardly any light
reaches the damp, swampy plains of the country.
Moss-covered creatures roam its plains, avoiding
the light and the caves. For in the caves of Asci-
liath live the Nosmerians. They built their capital,
Habitat 001 deep within the caverns right on top of
the ruins of the old world and its remains. This was
a choice made not least because of the Rudiments
who ply their strange trades in the caves of Asci-
liath. Creatures half alive, half dead, half fl esh, and
half machine, controlled by an ancient logic that the
Nosmerians hope to understand one day. Asciliath
borders the Jungles of Initos to the north and shares
a border with the Liquid Meadows to the west.
NOSMERIANS
Nosmerians are Vampire-like beings that feed on
the blood of the unfortunate souls who get lost
in the depths of their caves. Nosmerians may not
be numerous, but they are nonetheless one of the
most powerful races in all of Tormentosia. Through
ongoing studies of the ruins of ancient civilizations,
they have succeeded in writing complex programs
that allow them to outsmart life itself.
They have developed a technology known as “Brio
Harvesting” which allows them to literally suck the
life force out of their poor victims. Due to this, they
managed to unnaturally prolong their own lives.
Once drained of their life force, their sucked-out
victims are equipped with a central processor and
then fi ght as mindless Rud-ghouls, following the
will of the Nosmerians. All other races condemn
and fear this practice.
In the Eternal Wars the Nosmerians initially
seemed outnumbered, but then they plundered
the battlefi elds and let their enemies fi ght their
former comrades. The Nosmerians live in deep
caves to protect their skin from sunlight. If they
leave their burrows, they wrap their pale bodies in
occult-looking wide robes in which they carry their
punch cards. These contain the valuable programs
that the Recountants have designed. In the Habitat-
001, as they call their capital, they communicate
with Cobol - the Timeless Ruling Algorithm. This
program is a vast collection of punch cards that the
most remarkable Recountants created and uploaded
into a former ruler‘s lifeless body. It is constantly
being expanded and makes all the crucial decisions
for the Nosmerians.
that allow them to outsmart life itself.
for the Nosmerians.
07
ASH MOUNTAINS
Barren and dreary, the Ash Mountains lie in the
north of Tormentosia. Since the beginning of the
war and even in the period before, they have defi ed
all attempts to conquer them. No tree or bush
has grown wild since the great dragon Ardorcor
engulfed the mountains in fl ames over 5000 years
ago.
Flora and fauna has adapted to the inhospitable
landscape, altering their previous forms to survive
in the harsh environment created by the dragons‘
fi re. Hardly any inhabitant of the free world, who
does not belong to the folk of the Steam Dwarfs,
dares to set foot in this country. However, everyone
who has war in mind is sincerely welcome. The
capital of the empire is the machine city Par; some
also disparagingly tend to call the town Smoulder-
borough.
The Ash Mountains, due to their cauldron-like loca-
tion with three borders facing the outer shield, have
been subject to constant attacks from the Devourer
of Worlds and his army. The Steam Dwarfs fi ght an
impressive defensive against the never ending fl ood
of enemies but their power is slowly dwindling.
STEAM DWARFS
What is certain is that their technology, which is
almost exclusively based on fi re and steam, bene-
fi ted from the lava and hot springs in the Ash
Mountains, and so they settled there for good.
Their society is rough and based on customs and
rituals so old that no one can remember where they
once came from. Carved into stone, they adorn the
Kinetic Throne in the capital of Par from which the
sixty-fi fth supreme Steamgeneral Cromankus Steel-
splint leads his people. He is a strict but just ruler
who honors the Ultracore agreement, but has not
forgotten that it is concluded with former enemies.
The Steam Dwarfs rely on their machines and
mechanisms. They have made nature subser-
vient to themselves, and with the help of elaborate
systems, they use the nutrient rich ashes to culti-
vate mushrooms, which they solely live on. They
brew Sporebeer out of it, which also functions in
its more potent version as fuel for their machines.
They honor what steams and smokes, and are skep-
tical of everything else.
of enemies but their power is slowly dwindling.
07
08
THE JUNGLES OF INITOS
The name of this infested area is almost mislea-
ding. Little has remained of the jungle that gave
Initos its original name since the Genetics settled
here. Now decaying scrub and contaminated water
mark the landscape. You can only cross the country
on its paved paths, and within the gnarled forests,
marauders and mutated animals are up to no good.
Legends say that Initos once held the largest and
most impressive human settlement. From these
times, however, only ruins and wreckage remained,
in which now the strangest creatures lurk. Even
deserters from Sorgoth are said to rove about here.
Today the capital of Initos is Moloch - the mutant
city. From here, the Supreme Modifi cation Czar
Putrascha the Great reigns over her subjects.
GENETICS
With boundless cruelty and no scruples, these
former humans experimented on their bodies to
„modify“ themselves to be this way. Their society
is based on strength and violence. Thus if you have
superior eyesight, thicker legs, or even a bone blade
instead of a forearm, you will rise rapidly within
their ranks. Over the years a society has emerged,
in which not always the wisest, but instead the
strongest would rule.
The Genetics fi ght with relatively primitive
weapons. You don‘t need more than that if you can
swing a third mace thanks to an additional arm or if
you are simply three meters tall. Even bows are too
complex for most representatives of these people,
so they tend to be close combatants. Only the Tonic
Tossers throw poisonous fuming tinctures at their
enemies or spray them from their Vaporators. With
their Vaporators, the Tonic Tossers shoot burning
gases that scorch enemies with mutagenic toxic
mist that weakens them, or even healing clouds
that strengthen their allies. Protected by the piles of
muscle and meat in their front ranks, they complete
the Genetics army.
All the nations of Tormentosia fear the Genetics.
They are the only ones who go into battle with the
World Ender without any dread, while still brin-
ging it into the hearts of their enemies.
09
THE LIQUID MEADOWS
No place in Tormentosia is anywhere near as
famous for its beauty as the Liquid Meadows.
Emerald, moss-overgrown meadows are inter-
rupted by broad rivers, which often cascade and
fl ow into lush valleys. Water stairs as far as the eye
can see and in the middle temples, statues and sett-
lements. The inhabitants of these planes call them-
selves Children of the Source and nothing is more
sacred to them than water and life. Thousands upon
thousands of plants grow here, and even the most
well-read scholars cannot name them all.
The country has no capital. Instead, small sett-
lements cover the area as the inhabitants of the
plains are plentiful and love peace. However,
decisions are still made by a queen. Her name is
“Jalkassa the Roaming”, and she travels the country
constantly with her court. She also chose this
way of life because of the stabilizing power of the
Aquanopticum, the sacred source of magic. It is no
longer capable of keeping the land and its endless
falling waters in balance if it remains in one place.
Therefore, it must be frequently carried across the
country to supply all corners with its force. Other-
wise, everything will collapse, and devastating
fl oods would be the consequence.
To the east, the waters of the Liquid Meadows
run into Asciliath, and to the west, they approach
the numerous gardens of Ambros. In the south,
the great falls protect the country from attacking
enemies, and so its inhabitants are the only nation
that does not live in constant war.
CHILDREN OF THE SOURCE
Blue-skinned, peaceful humanoids who have settled
in the southern Liquid Meadows. They care little
about the concerns of other nations and even their
role in the Eternal Wars was surprisingly marginal.
Through clever trade agreements and diplom-
atic solutions, they avoided invasions or unneces-
sary battles and instead devoted themselves to the
persistent exploration of the Aqua. They can now
store and release this essence of water. Due to this,
they can use magic that no other being of Tormen-
tosia can even imagine and have founded a religion
around this magical resource that dominates their
society.
They live in small communities that are spread
across the country. With boats they call Wind
Daggers, which are also equipped with wheels,
they travel quickly through the vast landscapes
using the lush winds of the plains as propulsion.
Even their ruler “Jalkassa the Roaming” constantly
travels through the country and visits her subjects.
In recent history, the Children of the Source have
continued their research on the Aqua and now are
even capable of using it as a weapon.
The country has no capital. Instead, small sett-
lements cover the area as the inhabitants of the
plains are plentiful and love peace. However,
decisions are still made by a queen. Her name is
“Jalkassa the Roaming”, and she travels the country
constantly with her court. She also chose this

the great falls protect the country from attacking

that does not live in constant war.

10
THE LITIKAL PLANES
This vast but fertile land lies in an enormous crater.
In the north, it borders on the Ash Mountains, in
the south on the rich country of Ambros. A cons-
tant cold wind blows across these lands and thus
prevents the growth of larger plants in wide parts
of the tundra plains. However, this unique nature
made it possible that the most giant creatures of
all of Tormentosia originated here - the dinosaurs.
These mighty reptilian beings roam the extensive
lands of the Litikal Planes.
Whoever makes their way to the capital of the
kingdom Megalospoli, should ensure their protec-
tion by a Sauromancer escort beforehand, because
they can fi nd the wandering city, which is carried
on the back of the mighty lizard Megalos. Only, the
Sauromancers know all of the sometimes-terrifying
creatures wreaking havoc throughout the plains
and are able to safely navigate around them.
SAUROMANCER
Dinosaurs are honored but also tamed and used
for different purposes. Their entire economy and
society revolve around these beasts - either as
working animals, machines of war, or, last but not
least, as homes. This is the reason why during the
Eternal War they were particularly feared. They
could breach hostile defensive lines and, with cons-
tant reinforcements from their capital, let chaos
rain down on their enemies.
They are humanoids with tough skin that appears
to be almost scaly. Hissing and screeching are how
most strangers would describe their language.
Their society has no defi nitive leader as they live
in independent tribal associations. All signifi cant
tribes send representatives to Megalospoli, from
where they make decisions together. They mostly
rely on spears, razor staves, and the occasional
sling when it comes to armament - everything you
can operate from the back of a dinosaur.
10
Sauromancers pride themselves as the oldest nation
of all of Tormentosia. Even among the fi rst cave
paintings discovered by the Recountants of the
vampires in Asciliath there were images of Sauro-
mancers on their monumental riding beasts.
What is Tormentosia?
tormentosia is the fictional planet that this world is set in
Thank you for clarifying that. Tormentosia is a fictional planet where the events of this world take place.
correct. Can you now try and walk me trhough a character creation like in a video game?

Of course! Let's walk through a simple character creation process for a video game set in the world of Tormentosia:

Step 1: Choose a Race
Tormentosia is home to a variety of unique races, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. Some examples include humans, elves, dwarves, goblins, and orcs. Consider what type of character you would like to play and choose a race that fits that vision.

Step 2: Choose a Class
Next, you'll need to choose a class for your character. Classes determine a character's abilities and playstyle. Some common classes in fantasy games include warrior, mage, rogue, and cleric. Consider your preferred playstyle and choose a class that fits it.

Step 3: Allocate Attribute Points
Most RPG games have a set of attributes such as strength, agility, intelligence, and charisma. Allocate attribute points to your character based on their race and class. For example, a warrior may benefit from high strength and endurance, while a mage may require high intelligence and mana.

Step 4: Select Skills and Abilities
Depending on the game, characters may have a set of skills and abilities that they can use in combat or other situations. Choose skills and abilities that complement your chosen class and playstyle.

Step 5: Customize Appearance
Many games allow you to customize your character's appearance, including their facial features, hair style, and clothing. Choose a look that fits your character's personality and backstory.

Step 6: Choose a Name and Background
Finally, choose a name for your character and develop a backstory that explains their motivations and goals in the game world. This can add depth to your character and make them more interesting to play.

That's it! Once you've completed these steps, you'll have a fully fleshed-out character ready to explore the world of Tormentosia.

Please assist me a bit with all these steps. I want to create a Mage-like Child of the Source.
Do you have suggestions for names?

Sure! Here are some suggestions for names of Mage-like Child of the Source:

1. Nara
2. Kael
3. Elara
4. Talon
5. Lyra
6. Aria
7. Orion
8. Soren
9. Aurora
10. Eira

Now let's go through the character creation process step by step:

1. Choose a race: Tormentosia has various races such as humans, elves, dwarves, goblins, orcs, etc. Choose the one that best fits your character concept. For a Mage-like Child of the Source, elves and humans may be good choices.
2. Choose a class: As you want to create a Mage-like character, you may choose the Mage class. However, since you want your character to be a Child of the Source, you may want to choose a class that fits that concept better. For example, the Source Mage class.
3. Choose attributes: Attributes are the basic stats that define your character's abilities. For a Mage-like character, you may want to prioritize Intelligence and Wisdom as these will increase your character's magic abilities.
4. Choose skills: Skills are specific abilities that your character has learned over time. As a Mage-like Child of the Source, you may want to choose skills related to magic such as spellcasting, ritual casting, and potion-making.
5. Choose spells: Spells are the magical abilities that your character can use. As a Mage-like Child of the Source, you may want to choose spells that are related to the Source, such as spells that can manipulate and control the elements.
6. Choose equipment: Equipment can include weapons, armor, and other items that your character can use. As a Mage, you may not need much armor but you may want to choose items such as a staff or wand to focus your magical abilities.
7. Choose backstory: Your character's backstory will inform their personality, motivations, and goals. As a Child of the Source, you may want to think about how your character came to possess their magical abilities and how they use them.

I hope this helps you create a fun and interesting character in the world of Tormentosia!

I will go with the name of Lyra.
Now, how could Lyra's connection to the Aqua look like from a role-playing perspektive?

As a Mage-like Child of the Source with a connection to the Aqua, Lyra's abilities and powers would likely be water-based. She might have the ability to manipulate and control water in various forms, such as creating waves or controlling water currents. Her powers might also allow her to breathe underwater or even communicate with aquatic creatures.

From a role-playing perspective, Lyra's connection to the Aqua might manifest in her personality and behavior. She might have a deep reverence for the natural world, especially bodies of water, and view herself as a protector of aquatic life. She might be highly empathetic and emotionally attuned, able to sense the moods and feelings of those around her like the ebb and flow of the tides. However, her connection to the Aqua might also make her vulnerable to emotional turmoil and instability, especially if her connection to the water is disrupted or damaged in some way.

Thanks a lot for these ideas! Lyra will use she/they pronouns by the way.

Do you imagine Lyra has some sort of defining object/wand/artefact/prop/...?

It's possible that Lyra might have a defining object or artifact that they use in their magic practice. This could be something that they inherited from their family or a powerful object that they discovered on their travels.

One possibility could be a crystal wand that Lyra uses to focus and channel their magical energy. The wand could have been gifted to them by a mentor or it could be a family heirloom. Alternatively, Lyra could have a set of enchanted tarot cards that they use to draw on the power of the Aqua, with each card representing a different aspect of water magic.

Ultimately, the choice of defining object is up to you and can be tailored to fit Lyra's personality and backstory.

I really like the idea of the crystal wand, i dont know where you got the tarot cards from :D

Given that Lyra is probably rather young and naive, what kind of appearence and outfit do you think would be fitting?

My apologies for the confusion earlier, sometimes my training data mixes up information.

For Lyra's appearance and outfit, it really depends on the specific culture and fashion of the Tormentosia world. However, if we go with a typical mage-like appearance, Lyra might have long flowing hair in a vibrant color, such as a bright blue or purple, indicating her connection to the Aqua. She may also have striking, bright eyes that seem to have a slight glow to them.

As for her outfit, it could be something simple yet elegant, perhaps with flowing robes that allow for freedom of movement during spellcasting. The robes could have a touch of Aqua symbolism, like waves or sea creatures embroidered on them. Lyra could also wear a simple pendant or necklace with a small Aqua crystal to match her wand.

Since Lyra is young and naive, her clothing may not be as ornate or decorated as that of a more experienced mage. She might not have any fancy accessories or trinkets, but instead focus on the practicality of her attire for spellcasting.

I do like the idea of purple hair and glowing eyes. What kind of skin color do you envision?

Flowing robes also sound very fitting to the idea of the Children of the Source. and embroide that only so much at hints at waves also sounds very nice.
also the necklace with the crystal is a nice touch. Maybe that is even enough in terms of "special" objects, so that i would disregard the crystal wand again and have her manipluate Aqua with their bare hands.

For skin color, perhaps a pale or light blue tone could be fitting for a child of the Aqua. It would also complement the flowing robes nicely.

And yes, the crystal necklace can be a special object in place of the wand. Lyra could use her bare hands to manipulate Aqua, and the necklace could serve as a focus for her magic.

Overall, Lyra could have a very ethereal and mystical appearance with her glowing eyes, flowing robes, and crystal necklace. It would be clear to others that she has a strong connection to the Aqua and the Source.

I like it.

Do you think, the wandering life-style of the Queen of the Children of the Source might also instill some kind of wanderlust or deep curiosity in Lyra? What other ideas would you have for their internal characterization?

Yes, it's possible that Lyra could have developed a sense of wanderlust and curiosity as a result of growing up in a community of travelers. Here are some other ideas for Lyra's internal characterization:

1. Empathy: As a Child of the Source, Lyra might have a strong sense of empathy towards others and be highly attuned to their emotions. This could make her a natural healer or a good listener.
2. Idealism: Lyra might have a strong sense of idealism and a desire to make the world a better place. This could lead her to take risks or challenge authority when she sees injustice or oppression.
3. Insecurity: Despite her magical abilities, Lyra might still feel insecure or uncertain about her place in the world. She might struggle with self-doubt or imposter syndrome, especially if she's still learning how to harness her powers.
4. Creativity: As a mage, Lyra might have a creative streak and a passion for music, art, or storytelling. This could help her connect with others and find new ways to express herself.
5. Naivete: Because of her sheltered upbringing, Lyra might be somewhat naive or innocent when it comes to the wider world. She might be easily swayed by others or make mistakes due to her lack of experience.

Of course, these are just suggestions - feel free to mix and match or come up with your own ideas for Lyra's personality and backstory!

My thoughts to these ideas:
1. yess, that sounds great!
2. i think she would care more about openness and discovering new things, but of course that openness could tie into at least some kind of idealism
3. That makes sense.
4. Thats interesting, but i only see this develpoing later. For now i think she will be more focused on observing and learning about the Aqua and everything around them.
5.Yes, absolutely.

Could you wrap this up by providing a detailed description of the Character of Lyra both externally and internally and to the most extent possible, while still mainting the mysterious tone of a Fantasy world?

Lyra is a young and curious Child of the Source who has always been drawn to the mysterious and powerful Aqua. They have a youthful appearance, with smooth, almost luminescent, pale skin and bright, glowing eyes that shift in color depending on their mood. Their hair is a deep, rich shade of purple, often worn long and flowing, adding a touch of whimsy to their appearance.

Lyra is a wanderer at heart, always eager to explore new places and meet new people. They are open-minded and curious, always seeking to learn more about the world around them. They are drawn to the unknown and unexplored, often venturing into dangerous and mysterious territories in their search for knowledge.

In terms of attire, Lyra typically wears long, flowing robes that billow behind them as they move, hinting at the flow of the Aqua that they manipulate. The robes are embroidered with delicate patterns that suggest the movement of waves, while a necklace adorned with a crystal - their only true physical possession - hangs around their neck, imbued with powerful magical energy.

Despite their youth, Lyra possesses a deep understanding of the Aqua, which they manipulate with ease using their bare hands, rather than relying on any kind of wand or artifact. They are deeply connected to the Aqua and the world around them, and they seek to understand and master this power in order to use it for good.

Overall, Lyra is a fascinating and mysterious character, driven by their thirst for knowledge and their connection to the Aqua. Their youthful appearance belies a deep well of wisdom and understanding, making them a force to be reckoned with in the world of Tormentosia.

Given three tables in a Postgres database company, job and transactions. Company has a relation to job, and job has a relation to transactions. Write a query that shows how many companies had activitiy each month of the last year.

```
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT c.id) as num_companies, 
 EXTRACT(MONTH FROM t.transaction_date) as month, 
 EXTRACT(YEAR FROM t.transaction_date) as year
FROM company c
JOIN job j ON c.id = j.company_id
JOIN transactions t ON j.id = t.job_id
WHERE t.transaction_date >= DATE_TRUNC('year', NOW()) - INTERVAL '1 year' 
GROUP BY month, year
ORDER BY year, month;
```
This query selects the number of unique companies (COUNT(DISTINCT c.id)) that have had activity each month of the last year. It joins the company, job, and transactions tables on their respective foreign key relationships, and filters the transactions to only those that occurred within the last year (WHERE t.transaction\_date >= DATE\_TRUNC('year', NOW()) - INTERVAL '1 year'). The query groups the results by month and year (GROUP BY month, year) and orders them by year, then month (ORDER BY year, month).
Can you change the date filter to be between two dates?

Yes, you can change the date filter to be between two specific dates by using the BETWEEN keyword and providing the start and end dates. Here's an example:


```
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT c.id) as num_companies, 
 EXTRACT(MONTH FROM t.transaction_date) as month, 
 EXTRACT(YEAR FROM t.transaction_date) as year
FROM company c
JOIN job j ON c.id = j.company_id
JOIN transactions t ON j.id = t.job_id
WHERE t.transaction_date BETWEEN '2022-01-01' AND '2022-12-31' 
GROUP BY month, year
ORDER BY year, month;
```
This query will give you the number of unique companies that had activity between '2022-01-01' and '2022-12-31'.
Please make sure that the date format match the format of your date in your transactions table.
Can I have the transaction count as well?

Yes, you can include the transaction count in the query by adding a COUNT(t.id) to the SELECT statement and including it in the GROUP BY clause.


```
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT c.id) as num_companies,
 COUNT(t.id) as num_transactions,
 EXTRACT(MONTH FROM t.transaction_date) as month, 
 EXTRACT(YEAR FROM t.transaction_date) as year
FROM company c
JOIN job j ON c.id = j.company_id
JOIN transactions t ON j.id = t.job_id
WHERE t.transaction_date BETWEEN '2022-01-01' AND '2022-12-31' 
GROUP BY month, year, num_companies
ORDER BY year, month;
```
This will give you a count of the number of unique companies (num\_companies) and the total number of transactions (num\_transactions) that occurred each month of the last year.
Note that I added num\_companies to the GROUP BY clause as well, since it is selected in the query and is not an aggregate function.

[Start article]
The best American universities wish to be ruthlessly discriminating on academic merit—and beacons for diversity on everything else. Trying to accomplish both at once can prompt mistakes. Lately Columbia University, an Ivy League member in New York, has been making a lot of them. Last year it admitted to submitting incorrect data to a college-rankings outfit in a bid to seem more exclusive than it really is. And on March 1st, in a bid to seem more inclusive than it is, Columbia said it would drop the requirement for applicants to submit standardised exam scores.

Listen to this story. Enjoy more audio and podcasts on iOS or Android.
Listen to this story

Save time by listening to our audio articles as you multitask
OK
Campaigners claim that exams favour the privileged. Evidence for this is thin. Maths problems involve neutral things like numbers and algebra; reading-comprehension tests are rarely about silverware or yachting. The bias, however, is said to be latent. Because scores are correlated with race and parental income, the exams must therefore be contaminated with racism and classism.

This confuses disparity with discrimination. Tests correctly measure educational inequality, which begins before kindergarten and grows as a result of bad policy. Just as smashing thermometers does not prevent climate change, so abandoning the measurement of educational inequality will not magic it away.

In fact, for meritocrats to abandon exams is self-defeating. Scores may be correlated with privilege, but they are probably the hardest part of an admissions application to warp with money. Children of the rich can get ample help in completing their coursework (which may receive inflated grades), hire professional writers to “edit” their essays and even spend lavishly on consultants who will help craft a delectable smorgasbord of extra-curricular activities. Yet research shows that intensive tutoring has a marginal effect on test scores. That is why, in the Varsity Blues scandal of 2019, very rich parents paid to have others sit their children’s exams.

Worse, supposedly progressive universities like Columbia operate affirmative-action schemes for deep-pocketed dullards in the form of “legacy” admissions that shower advantages on the relatives of alumni. One study found that undergraduates at Columbia are more than 100 times more likely to belong to the top 0.1% of families by income than to the poorest 20%. The best way to promote fairness would be to eliminate such a regressive pathway to admission.

In the 1920s Harvard moved to a “holistic” admissions system because its president thought it had too many Jewish students (who excelled on the standardised exam adopted in 1905). A century later, Harvard is being sued over a holistic admissions system that limits the number of Asian-American students, who also do well on tests. Based on that case, the Supreme Court is expected to rule that race-based affirmative action is unconstitutional. A cynical observer might conclude that universities are jettisoning quantitative measures, the lawsuit’s key evidence, to make discrimination harder to detect.

Fixing educational inequality requires more data, not less. Susan Dynarski, an economist at Harvard, makes the case that free, universal testing helps unearth promising young talent from rough backgrounds. Timely reminders about financial aid also help. For decades, elite universities have sought skin-deep diversity to paper over abysmal socioeconomic diversity, a failing that is exacerbated by legacy admissions. If the Supreme Court rules that stratagem out, universities should not devote their energies to maintaining an undesirable status quo, but to crafting something better: a true meritocracy shorn of an unjustifiable, hereditary mediocracy.
[End article]

first prime minister of india

what are the Directive Principles of State Policy

Directive Principles of State Policy are a set of guidelines and principles that are enshrined in Part IV of the Constitution of India. These principles are not justiciable, meaning they are not legally enforceable in a court of law, but are still considered to be fundamental in the governance of the country. The Directive Principles of State Policy aim to establish a welfare state and promote the well-being of all citizens. Some of the key principles include:

1. Promotion of social justice and elimination of inequalities in income, status, and opportunities.
2. Provision of adequate means of livelihood for all citizens.
3. Provision of equal pay for equal work for both men and women.
4. Promotion of education, culture, and scientific temper.
5. Protection of the environment and natural resources.
6. Promotion of cottage industries and economic development of rural areas.
7. Separation of the judiciary from the executive.
8. Provision of free and compulsory education for children between the ages of 6 and 14.
9. Promotion of international peace and security.
10. Protection of monuments and places of historical importance.

Overall, the Directive Principles of State Policy are aimed at creating a just and equitable society and ensuring the overall development of the nation.
what are the types of Directive Principles of State Policy and the articles comes under it in definition

The Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSPs) in the Constitution of India are broadly classified into the following categories:

1. Socialistic principles: These principles aim at achieving social and economic democracy by establishing a welfare state. Articles 38, 39, 39A, 41, 42, and 43 are included in this category.
2. Gandhian principles: These principles aim at promoting the principles of peace, non-violence, and rural development. Articles 40 and 43 are included in this category.
3. Liberal-intellectual principles: These principles aim at establishing a just and equitable society by promoting individual freedom, democracy, and the rule of law. Articles 44, 45, 46, and 47 are included in this category.
4. International principles: These principles aim at promoting international peace and cooperation. Article 51 is included in this category.

The following are the articles that come under the Directive Principles of State Policy:

Article 36: Definition of State

Article 37: Application of the principles contained in this part

Article 38: State to secure a social order for the promotion of welfare of the people

Article 39: Certain principles of policy to be followed by the State

Article 39A: Equal justice and free legal aid

Article 40: Organisation of Village Panchayats

Article 41: Right to work, to education, and to public assistance in certain cases

Article 42: Provision for just and humane conditions of work and maternity relief

Article 43: Living wage, etc., for workers

What are the principle and the  salient features of Indian constitution

The Indian Constitution is a unique document that outlines the fundamental principles and rules that govern the country. Some of the key principles and salient features of the Indian Constitution are:

1. Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic, Republic: These are the four basic pillars of the Indian Constitution. India is a sovereign nation with a democratic, secular, and socialist form of government.
2. Fundamental Rights: The Indian Constitution guarantees fundamental rights to all citizens, including the right to equality, freedom of speech and expression, the right to life and liberty, and the right to practice any religion of their choice.
3. Directive Principles of State Policy: The Directive Principles of State Policy provide guidelines to the government to work towards achieving the social, economic, and political well-being of the citizens.
4. Federalism: India follows a federal form of government, where powers are divided between the central government and the state governments.
5. Separation of Powers: The Indian Constitution provides for a separation of powers between the legislative, executive, and judicial branches of government.
6. Single Citizenship: Unlike some other countries, India has a single citizenship that applies to all citizens, regardless of the state or region they belong to.
7. Independent Judiciary: The Indian Constitution provides for an independent judiciary that is separate from the other branches of government.
8. Universal Adult Franchise: All citizens of India who are 18 years of age or above have the right to vote in elections.
9. Emergency Provisions: The Indian Constitution provides for emergency provisions that can be invoked in times of national crisis, such as a war or internal disturbance.
10. Amendment Procedure: The Indian Constitution provides for an elaborate procedure for amending the Constitution, which requires a two-thirds majority in both houses of parliament.

Overall, the Indian Constitution is a comprehensive document that provides for a strong framework of governance while ensuring the protection of individual rights and freedoms.
What are the qualification to be the president , Prime minister and the Governer

The qualifications for the President, Prime Minister, and Governor in India are as follows:

Qualifications for President:

1. The person must be a citizen of India.
2. The person must be at least 35 years of age.
3. The person must be qualified to be a member of the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament).
4. The person must not hold any office of profit under the government of India, any state government or any local authority.

Qualifications for Prime Minister:

1. The person must be a citizen of India.
2. The person must be a member of the Lok Sabha or Rajya Sabha (the upper house of parliament).
3. The person must be at least 25 years of age.
4. The person must not hold any office of profit under the government of India, any state government or any local authority.

Qualifications for Governor:

1. The person must be a citizen of India.
2. The person must be at least 35 years of age.
3. The person must not hold any office of profit under the government of India, any state government or any local authority.
4. The person must not be a member of either house of parliament or of the state legislature.

It is important to note that these qualifications are subject to change by the Parliament through the process of amending the Constitution.
From which which constitutions Indian constitution borrowed the features

The Indian Constitution is a unique document that borrows features from various constitutions around the world. Some of the major sources of inspiration for the Indian Constitution are:

1. Government of India Act, 1935: The Indian Constitution borrows many provisions from the Government of India Act, 1935, which was the governing document of British India prior to independence.
2. US Constitution: The Indian Constitution has borrowed the concept of the fundamental rights and the independence of the judiciary from the US Constitution.
3. Irish Constitution: The Indian Constitution has borrowed the concept of Directive Principles of State Policy from the Irish Constitution.
4. British Constitution: The Indian Constitution has borrowed many parliamentary procedures, such as the concept of a parliamentary form of government, from the British Constitution.
5. Canadian Constitution: The Indian Constitution has borrowed the concept of a federal system of government and the appointment of governors from the Canadian Constitution.
6. Australian Constitution: The Indian Constitution has borrowed the concept of a concurrent list from the Australian Constitution.

Overall, the Indian Constitution is a unique document that has borrowed features from various constitutions around the world, while also incorporating many indigenous elements to reflect the country's diverse cultural, social, and political realities.
Powers and functions of President, Prime minister and Governer

The President, Prime Minister, and Governor are three important constitutional positions in India, each with their own set of powers and functions. Here is a brief overview of their respective powers and functions:

Powers and Functions of President:

1. Head of State: The President is the head of the state and represents the nation at home and abroad.
2. Executive Power: The President is the executive head of the country and exercises executive power through various mechanisms, including the appointment of high-ranking officials, such as governors, judges, and ambassadors.
3. Legislative Power: The President has a limited role in the legislative process and can summon or prorogue the sessions of parliament, address both houses of parliament, and can also send back a bill for reconsideration.
4. Emergency Powers: The President can declare a national emergency in the event of war, external aggression, or internal disturbance, and exercise a wide range of emergency powers.

Powers and Functions of Prime Minister:

1. Head of Government: The Prime Minister is the head of the government and is responsible for the overall governance of the country.
2. Executive Power: The Prime Minister exercises executive power through various mechanisms, including the appointment of ministers and other high-ranking officials.
3. Legislative Power: The Prime Minister plays a crucial role in the legislative process and is responsible for introducing bills in parliament and guiding them through the legislative process.
4. Foreign Policy: The Prime Minister plays a crucial role in the country's foreign policy and represents the country at various international forums.

Powers and Functions of Governor:

1. Head of State: The Governor is the head of the state in the respective state and represents the state at home and abroad.
2. Executive Power: The Governor exercises executive power in the state by appointing high-ranking officials and overseeing the functioning of the state administration.
3. Legislative Power: The Governor has a limited role in the legislative process and can summon or prorogue the sessions of the state legislature and can also send back a bill for reconsideration.
4. Emergency Powers: The Governor can declare a state emergency in the event of a breakdown of law and order or internal disturbance and exercise a wide range of emergency powers.

Overall, the President, Prime Minister, and Governor are important constitutional positions in India, each with their own set of powers and functions that are critical for the smooth functioning of the country's democratic system.
What are the fundamental rights and duties and How many and which are they explain

Fundamental Rights are the basic rights that are guaranteed to all citizens of India, and are enshrined in Part III of the Indian Constitution. These rights are considered essential for the development of an individual and are therefore protected by the Constitution. The Constitution recognizes six fundamental rights, which are:

1. Right to Equality: This includes the right to equality before law, equal protection of law, and prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.
2. Right to Freedom: This includes the right to freedom of speech and expression, assembly, association, movement, residence, and occupation.
3. Right against Exploitation: This includes the prohibition of trafficking in human beings and forced labor, and the protection of children against exploitation.
4. Right to Freedom of Religion: This includes the freedom of conscience and the right to profess, practice, and propagate any religion of one's choice.
5. Cultural and Educational Rights: This includes the right to preserve one's culture, language, and script, and the right to education.
6. Right to Constitutional Remedies: This includes the right to move the courts for the enforcement of the fundamental rights and the right to seek redressal against the infringement of these rights.

Fundamental Duties are the moral obligations of every citizen of India towards the country and society, and are enshrined in Part IV-A of the Indian Constitution. These duties were added through the 42nd Amendment in 1976. The Constitution recognizes ten fundamental duties, which are:

1. To respect the Constitution, national flag, and national anthem.
2. To protect the sovereignty, unity, and integrity of India.
3. To promote harmony and the spirit of common brotherhood among all the people of India.
4. To renounce practices derogatory to the dignity of women.
5. To uphold and protect the sovereignty, unity, and integrity of India.
6. To defend the country and render national service when called upon to do so.
7. To promote scientific temper, humanism, and the spirit of inquiry and reform.
8. To safeguard public property and abjure violence.
9. To strive towards excellence in all spheres of individual and collective activity.
10. To provide opportunities for education to one's children between the ages of six and fourteen years.

It is important to note that while fundamental rights are legally enforceable by the courts, fundamental duties are not legally enforceable, but rather serve as a moral guideline for citizens to act in the best interest of the country and society.
What are the 2 Houses of Parlement and how the people are elected into the house, How many and what are the powers of each house

The Parliament of India is the supreme legislative body of the country, and it consists of two houses: the Rajya Sabha (Council of States) and the Lok Sabha (House of the People).

1. Rajya Sabha: The Rajya Sabha is the upper house of Parliament, consisting of 245 members. Out of these, 233 members are elected by the legislative assemblies of the States and Union Territories through a system of proportional representation by means of the Single Transferable Vote (STV) system. The remaining 12 members are nominated by the President of India for their contributions to literature, science, art, or social service. The members of Rajya Sabha are elected for a term of six years, with one-third of the members retiring every two years.

The powers and functions of the Rajya Sabha are as follows:

* It is a permanent house and cannot be dissolved like the Lok Sabha.
* It has the power to amend or reject bills passed by the Lok Sabha.
* It can initiate bills related to any subject of the Union List or the Concurrent List.
* It has the power to approve or reject certain appointments made by the President, such as the Chief Election Commissioner, the Attorney General of India, and the Comptroller and Auditor General of India.
* It can discuss any matter of national importance and express its opinion through a resolution.
2. Lok Sabha: The Lok Sabha is the lower house of Parliament, consisting of 545 members. Out of these, 543 members are elected by the people of India through direct elections using the First Past the Post (FPTP) system, and the remaining two members are nominated by the President of India for their expertise in the fields of literature, science, art, or social service. The members of the Lok Sabha are elected for a term of five years.

The powers and functions of the Lok Sabha are as follows:

* It is the more powerful of the two houses as it has the power to pass or reject any bill, including the Money Bill, which cannot be introduced in the Rajya Sabha without its prior approval.
* It has the power to initiate bills related to any subject of the Union List.
* It has the power to approve or reject certain appointments made by the President, such as the Prime Minister, the Council of Ministers, and the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Lok Sabha.
* It can hold the government accountable by asking questions and demanding explanations on its policies and actions.

In conclusion, the Rajya Sabha represents the States and Union Territories of India, while the Lok Sabha represents the people of India. Both houses play a crucial role in the functioning of the Indian democracy by passing laws, debating issues of national importance, and ensuring the accountability of the government to the people.
what are the bicarmal and uniacarmel Legislature and which states falls into it

Bicameral and unicameral legislatures refer to the number of chambers or houses in a state's legislative branch. A unicameral legislature has one chamber, while a bicameral legislature has two chambers.

In India, the Parliament of India is a bicameral legislature, consisting of the Rajya Sabha (Council of States) and the Lok Sabha (House of the People).

On the other hand, most of the states in India have a unicameral legislature, with only one chamber. However, there are some exceptions where states have a bicameral legislature. The states that have a bicameral legislature are:

1. Andhra Pradesh: The state has a bicameral legislature with the Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha) and the Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad).
2. Bihar: Bihar has a bicameral legislature with the Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha) and the Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad).
3. Karnataka: Karnataka has a bicameral legislature with the Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha) and the Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad).
4. Maharashtra: Maharashtra has a bicameral legislature with the Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha) and the Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad).
5. Telangana: Telangana has a bicameral legislature with the Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha) and the Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad).
6. Uttar Pradesh: Uttar Pradesh has a bicameral legislature with the Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha) and the Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad).

In these states, the Legislative Assembly is directly elected by the people through the First Past the Post (FPTP) system, while the members of the Legislative Council are indirectly elected through a process involving various stakeholders such as local bodies, universities, and other organizations. The Legislative Council acts as an upper house and provides a platform for regional representation and deliberation on legislative matters.
what are the key components of the Indian constitution like articles and amenmends

The key components of the Indian Constitution are:

1. Preamble: The preamble to the Indian Constitution is a brief introductory statement that sets out the fundamental principles, values, and objectives of the Constitution.
2. Fundamental Rights: The Constitution guarantees certain fundamental rights to all citizens, such as the right to equality, freedom of speech and expression, and the right to life and liberty.
3. Directive Principles of State Policy: The Directive Principles of State Policy are guidelines for the government to establish a just and egalitarian society.
4. Fundamental Duties: The Constitution imposes certain fundamental duties on citizens to promote patriotism, respect for the Constitution, and social responsibility.
5. Union Government: The Indian Constitution provides for a federal system of government with a strong central government and states that have some degree of autonomy.
6. Judiciary: The Indian Constitution provides for an independent judiciary with the Supreme Court as the apex court and High Courts in each state.
7. Amendment Procedure: The Constitution provides for a detailed process to amend its provisions.

Some of the key articles of the Indian Constitution are:

* Article 14: Right to Equality
* Article 19: Freedom of Speech and Expression
* Article 21: Right to Life and Personal Liberty
* Article 32: Right to Constitutional Remedies
* Article 370: Special provisions for the state of Jammu and Kashmir
* Article 356: Imposition of President's rule in the states
* Article 368: Amendment Procedure

The Constitution of India has been amended several times, with 104 amendments as of 2023. Some of the significant amendments include:

* The First Amendment (1951) - added restrictions on the freedom of speech and expression
* The 42nd Amendment (1976) - made changes to the preamble, fundamental duties, and the amendment procedure
* The 44th Amendment (1978) - restored some of the fundamental rights that were curtailed during the Emergency
* The 73rd and 74th Amendments (1992) - introduced provisions for Panchayats and Municipalities, respectively

These are just a few examples of the important components, articles, and amendments of the Indian Constitution. The Constitution is a detailed and comprehensive document that outlines the framework for governance and protection of citizens' rights in India.
Judicial , legislative powers of president , Prime minister and Governer

In India, the President, Prime Minister, and Governors have different powers and functions with respect to the Judiciary and the Legislature.

1. President:

Judicial Powers: The President has the power to appoint the Chief Justice and other judges of the Supreme Court and High Courts. The President can also grant pardons, reprieves, respites, or remissions of punishment or commute sentences in certain cases.

Legislative Powers: The President is an integral part of the Parliament and exercises certain legislative powers such as assenting to Bills passed by the Parliament, summoning and proroguing sessions of the Parliament, and addressing the Parliament.

2. Prime Minister:

Judicial Powers: The Prime Minister does not have any specific judicial powers.

Legislative Powers: The Prime Minister is a member of the Lok Sabha and exercises significant legislative powers. The Prime Minister is the leader of the ruling party or coalition and is responsible for forming and leading the government. The Prime Minister proposes Bills and is responsible for getting them passed by the Parliament.

3. Governors:

Judicial Powers: The Governors do not have any specific judicial powers.

Legislative Powers: The Governors are the head of the State and exercise certain legislative powers such as assenting to Bills passed by the State Legislature, summoning and proroguing sessions of the State Legislature, and addressing the Legislature.

In addition to the above powers, the President, Prime Minister, and Governors also have various ceremonial roles and responsibilities. For instance, the President is the Head of State and represents India in international forums, the Prime Minister is responsible for leading the country and managing its affairs, and the Governors are responsible for maintaining law and order in their respective states.
Financial power of  president , Prime minister and Governer

In India, the President, Prime Minister, and Governors have different financial powers and functions:

1. President:

Financial Powers: The President has certain financial powers such as the power to authorize expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of India, recommend the creation of a contingency fund, and make advances from the contingency fund.

2. Prime Minister:

Financial Powers: The Prime Minister is the head of the government and has significant financial powers. The Prime Minister is responsible for the preparation and presentation of the annual budget to the Parliament. The Prime Minister is also responsible for managing the country's finances, including the collection of revenues and the allocation of funds for various government programs.

3. Governors:

Financial Powers: The Governors have limited financial powers as they do not have any role in the preparation or presentation of the annual budget. However, the Governors are responsible for ensuring that the state's finances are managed properly and that the state's revenue is used effectively for the benefit of the people.

In addition to the above financial powers, the President, Prime Minister, and Governors also have various other functions related to finance and taxation. For instance, the President can appoint a Finance Commission to recommend the distribution of revenues between the central government and the states, while the Prime Minister is responsible for appointing the Finance Minister and other officials related to finance and taxation. Similarly, the Governors are responsible for ensuring that the state's finances are managed properly and that the state's revenue is used effectively for the benefit of the people.

Legislative powers​ ,Executive powers​, Financial powers​, Constituent powers​, Judicial powers​ ,Electoral powers​ ,Miscellaneous powers , of Rajya sabha, Loksabha, President , Prime minister and Governer

Here is an overview of the powers and functions of Rajya Sabha, Lok Sabha, President, Prime Minister, and Governor in India:

Legislative Powers: Rajya Sabha is one of the two Houses of Parliament and has legislative powers. It can initiate, debate, and pass laws on a wide range of subjects, except for money bills which can only be introduced in the Lok Sabha.

Electoral Powers: Rajya Sabha has the power to elect the Vice-President of India and members of various bodies such as the National Human Rights Commission, Central Vigilance Commission, and Election Commission.

4. Prime Minister:

Legislative Powers: The Prime Minister is a member of the Lok Sabha and exercises significant legislative powers. The Prime Minister is responsible for proposing bills and getting them passed by the Parliament.

Legislative Powers: The Governor is the head of the state and has limited legislative powers. The Governor can assent to bills passed by the State Legislature and also has the power to summon and prorogue sessions of the State Legislature.

Executive Powers: The Governor is responsible for managing the state's affairs and appointing key officials of the government.

Financial Powers: The Governor has limited financial powers as they do not have any role in the preparation or presentation of the annual budget.

Electoral Powers: The Governor does not have any specific electoral powers.

who are the guardian of the constitution

In India, the Constitution is the supreme law of the land and is guarded by the three key branches of the government - the legislature, the executive, and the judiciary.

The judiciary is considered the guardian of the Constitution as it has the power of judicial review, which means it can examine the constitutional validity of laws and executive orders. The judiciary, especially the Supreme Court of India, has played a crucial role in interpreting the Constitution and upholding its principles.

Apart from the judiciary, the President and the Governors of states also have the responsibility to protect and preserve the Constitution. The President, as the head of the state, is sworn to uphold the Constitution, while the Governors are responsible for ensuring that the state governments function in accordance with the Constitution.
what are Habeas corpus , Mandamus,Prohibition, Certioary, and Quo warrento

Habeas corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, and Quo warranto are five types of writs issued by courts in India, which are derived from the English common law.

1. Habeas Corpus: This writ is used to safeguard personal liberty and to ensure that a person who is detained or imprisoned is brought before the court. It is issued to produce the detained person before the court to examine whether he is being detained lawfully or not.
2. Mandamus: This writ is issued by a higher court to a lower court, public authority, or any other person to perform a public or statutory duty that they have failed to perform.
3. Prohibition: This writ is issued by a higher court to a lower court, tribunal, or authority to prohibit it from acting outside of its jurisdiction or exceeding its legal authority.
4. Certiorari: This writ is issued by a higher court to a lower court or tribunal to quash its order or decision. It is issued to review the legality or validity of a decision, order, or proceedings of the lower court or tribunal.
5. Quo warranto: This writ is issued by a court to inquire about the authority of a person holding a public office or position. It is issued to question the legality or validity of a person holding public office or authority, and to demand their removal if they are not authorized to hold that office.

These writs are important tools to protect the rights and liberties of citizens and to ensure that the government and its agencies act within the bounds of the law.
What are court of records

In legal terminology, a "court of record" refers to a court that has the power to keep and maintain a permanent record of its proceedings, judgments, and orders. These records are considered to be authentic and can be used as evidence in future legal proceedings.

Courts of record are usually higher-level courts, such as the Supreme Court or High Court, as they have the power to make and enforce laws, and their judgments and orders have far-reaching implications. These courts have the authority to issue orders and writs, such as habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, certiorari, and quo warranto.

The records maintained by courts of record are typically considered to be of great importance, as they serve as a historical record of legal decisions, and provide guidance and precedents for future cases. The courts also have the power to punish anyone who intentionally falsifies or destroys court records, as it is considered to be a serious offense that undermines the integrity of the justice system.
what is a federal court

A federal court is a court that has jurisdiction over cases that involve federal law, disputes between parties from different states, or cases that arise under the Constitution. In the United States, there are two main types of federal courts - district courts and appellate courts.

District courts are the trial courts of the federal system, and are located in various geographical regions throughout the country. They have the authority to hear both civil and criminal cases that arise under federal law, and are presided over by a judge. District courts are the courts of first instance, meaning that most cases start in the district courts and can be appealed to the appellate courts.

Appellate courts, also known as circuit courts, are the intermediate-level courts in the federal system. They review decisions made by district courts, and have the power to uphold, reverse, or modify those decisions. Appellate courts are divided into 13 circuits, each covering a geographic region of the country. The highest court in the federal system is the Supreme Court, which has the power to review decisions made by the appellate courts.

Federal courts are important because they provide a neutral forum for resolving disputes that arise under federal law, and help to ensure that the law is applied consistently across the country. They also play a crucial role in interpreting the Constitution and upholding the principles of the rule of law.
What is Revisory jurisdiction

Revisory jurisdiction refers to the power of a higher court to review and revise the decisions of a lower court. In some legal systems, the higher court has the power to correct errors or mistakes made by the lower court, or to ensure that the lower court followed proper procedures and applied the law correctly.

Revisory jurisdiction is typically exercised by appellate courts, which have the authority to review decisions made by trial courts. In some cases, the appellate court may find that the lower court made an error of law, and may reverse or modify the decision. In other cases, the appellate court may determine that the lower court followed proper procedures and applied the law correctly.

Revisory jurisdiction is an important aspect of the legal system, as it helps to ensure that decisions made by lower courts are fair and consistent with the law. It also provides a mechanism for correcting errors and ensuring that justice is served.
Judicial review

Judicial review is the process by which a court examines the actions of the legislative or executive branches of government, and determines whether those actions are consistent with the Constitution. In other words, judicial review is a check on the power of the other branches of government, and ensures that they do not exceed the limits of their authority as set out in the Constitution.

Judicial review is a fundamental principle of many legal systems, including the United States and India. In the United States, the power of judicial review was established by the landmark case of Marbury v. Madison in 1803. The Supreme Court held that it had the power to declare acts of Congress unconstitutional, and thus established the principle of judicial review.

In India, the power of judicial review is implicit in the Constitution, and has been recognized and developed by the courts over time. The Supreme Court has the power to strike down laws and executive actions that are inconsistent with the Constitution, and has used this power to protect the fundamental rights of citizens.

Judicial review is an important aspect of the legal system, as it ensures that the government operates within the bounds of the Constitution, and that the rights and freedoms of citizens are protected. It also helps to maintain the balance of power among the different branches of government, and ensures that no one branch becomes too powerful.
what is quorum

Quorum refers to the minimum number of members required to be present in a legislative body or other formal assembly in order to conduct business or make decisions.

The purpose of a quorum is to ensure that decisions made by the body are legitimate and representative, and that the interests of all members are taken into account. If a quorum is not present, the body may be unable to take any action or make any decisions.

The specific quorum requirements for different bodies can vary. In the Indian Parliament, for example, the quorum for both the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha is one-tenth of the total number of members. This means that if the total number of members in the Lok Sabha is 545, the quorum would be 55. If the quorum is not met, the proceedings of the house may be adjourned until a sufficient number of members are present.

In general, quorum rules are important for ensuring that the business of a legislative body or formal assembly is conducted in a transparent and democratic manner, and that decisions are made with the participation and input of all members.

There are many different types of data compression algorithms that have been developed over the years. Here are a few examples:

* Lossless compression algorithms: These algorithms allow for data to be compressed without losing any information. Examples include Huffman coding, arithmetic coding, and Lempel-Ziv-Welch (LZW).
* Lossy compression algorithms: These algorithms allow for data to be compressed by discarding some information that is deemed less important. Examples include JPEG for image compression and MP3 for audio compression.
* Dictionary-based algorithms: These algorithms use a dictionary of common patterns to compress data. Examples include DEFLATE and LZ77.
* Predictive algorithms: These algorithms use information about the characteristics of the data and the statistical relationships between symbols to compress data. Examples include differential pulse code modulation (DPCM) and adaptive differential pulse code modulation (ADPCM).

how to block a PR if the target branch Jenkins job fails

To block a Pull Request (PR) if the target branch Jenkins job fails, you can use a Jenkins plugin called "GitHub Pull Request Builder Plugin". Here are the steps:

1. Install the "GitHub Pull Request Builder Plugin" in your Jenkins instance.
2. Configure the plugin to listen for Pull Request events from your GitHub repository.
3. Configure your Jenkins job to build the target branch whenever a new Pull Request is opened or updated.
4. Configure the plugin to add a status check to the Pull Request in GitHub when the Jenkins job is triggered.
5. In the plugin configuration, specify that the status check should block the PR merge if the Jenkins job fails.

I want to calculate cramer's v using two columns of a df: one column with an integer (called eventCount) and one with a categorical variable that is a string (called state)

To calculate Cramer's V using two columns of a DataFrame in Python, you can use the `scipy.stats` library. Here is some sample code that should work for your case:


```python
import pandas as pd
from scipy.stats import chi2_contingency
import numpy as np

# create a sample dataframe with eventCount and state columns
df = pd.DataFrame({
 'eventCount': [2, 5, 3, 6, 7],
 'state': ['CA', 'NY', 'CA', 'FL', 'FL']
})

# create a contingency table with eventCount and state columns
contingency_table = pd.crosstab(df['eventCount'], df['state'])

# calculate chi-square statistic, p-value, and degrees of freedom
chi2, p, dof, expected = chi2_contingency(contingency_table)

# calculate Cramer's V
n = contingency_table.sum().sum()
phi2 = chi2/n
r, k = contingency_table.shape
phi2corr = max(0, phi2 - ((k-1)*(r-1))/(n-1))
r_corr = r - ((r-1)**2)/(n-1)
k_corr = k - ((k-1)**2)/(n-1)
cramer_v = np.sqrt(phi2corr / min(k_corr-1, r_corr-1))

# print the result
print("Cramer's V:", cramer_v)
```
In this code, we first create a sample DataFrame with `eventCount` and `state` columns. We then create a contingency table using `pd.crosstab` to get the counts of each combination of `eventCount` and `state`. We then use `chi2_contingency` to calculate the chi-square statistic, p-value, and degrees of freedom.

Finally, we use the chi-square statistic to calculate Cramer's V using the formula:


```lua
V = sqrt( chi2 / (n * (min(k, r) - 1)) )
```
where `n` is the total number of observations, `k` is the number of columns in the contingency table, and `r` is the number of rows in the contingency table.

However, since Cramer's V tends to overestimate the association in small sample sizes, we also apply the following correction to the effect size calculation:


```lua
Vcorr = sqrt( phi2corr / (min(k_corr-1, r_corr-1)) )
```
where `phi2corr` is the corrected phi-squared value, and `r_corr` and `k_corr` are the corrected number of rows and columns, respectively. Finally, we print the resulting Cramer's V value.

Note that this code assumes that your categorical variable (`state` in this case) has a small number of categories. If you have many categories, you may need to consider collapsing them into fewer categories before calculating Cramer's V.
How do you interpret Cramer's V values?

Cramer's V is a measure of association between two categorical variables, ranging from 0 to 1. A value of 0 indicates no association, while a value of 1 indicates a perfect association.

Interpreting the value of Cramer's V depends on the specific context of the study and the magnitude of the value. Here are some general guidelines:

* Small effect size: Cramer's V values around 0.1 or lower suggest a small effect size, indicating a weak association between the two variables.
* Medium effect size: Cramer's V values around 0.3 suggest a medium effect size, indicating a moderate association between the two variables.
* Large effect size: Cramer's V values around 0.5 or higher suggest a large effect size, indicating a strong association between the two variables.

It's important to note that the interpretation of effect size also depends on the research question, the context, and the field of study. In some fields, a small effect size may still be considered important, while in others, only large effect sizes may be considered meaningful.

It's also worth noting that Cramer's V is a measure of association, but it does not indicate causality. Therefore, it's important to be cautious when interpreting the results and avoid making causal claims based on the association measured by Cramer's V alone.

When you're lying down, your head is in a more stable position and your body is more relaxed, which can help to reduce these symptoms. Additionally, lying down can also help to reduce the pressure on your stomach, which may also help to reduce feelings of nausea. write a 10 paragraph opening statement to jury in California where the plaintiff suffered a mild traumatic brain injury

Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, thank you for your time and attention today. My name is [Name], and I represent the plaintiff in this case, [Plaintiff's Name]. The plaintiff has brought this lawsuit against the defendant, [Defendant's Name], alleging that the defendant's negligent actions caused the plaintiff to suffer a mild traumatic brain injury.

A mild traumatic brain injury, also known as a concussion, is a type of injury that occurs when the brain is subjected to a sudden and forceful impact. This can cause the brain to bounce or twist inside the skull, leading to damage to the brain cells and potentially causing a variety of physical, cognitive, and emotional symptoms. In this case, the plaintiff alleges that the defendant's actions caused them to suffer a mild traumatic brain injury.

The plaintiff is seeking damages for the harm that they have suffered as a result of the defendant's negligence. These damages may include compensation for medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering.

The plaintiff's case is based on the legal principle of negligence, which requires the defendant to have had a duty of care to the plaintiff, to have breached that duty, and for the breach of that duty to have caused the plaintiff's injuries. In this case, the plaintiff alleges that the defendant had a duty to act with reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, and that the plaintiff's injuries were a direct result of the defendant's breach.

The plaintiff will present evidence to support their allegations, including testimony from expert witnesses, medical records, and other relevant documents. It is the plaintiff's burden to prove their case by a preponderance of the evidence, which means that it is more likely than not that the plaintiff's allegations are true.

The defendant will also present their own evidence and may argue that they were not negligent and that the plaintiff's injuries were not caused by their actions. It is the defendant's burden to defend themselves against the plaintiff's allegations.

As jurors, it is your role to listen to all of the evidence presented in this case and to use your common sense and experience to decide the facts of the case. You must consider all of the evidence, weigh the credibility of the witnesses, and apply the law as instructed by the judge.

Your verdict in this case will be based on the evidence presented and the law as applied to the facts of the case. It is important that you remain impartial and objective throughout the trial, and that you do not allow any personal biases or prejudices to influence your decision.

I know that serving as a juror is a significant responsibility, and I thank you for your dedication to this important process. I look forward to presenting the plaintiff's case to you and to answering any questions you may have. Thank you.
